title: Prenatal diagnosis of a de novo 15q11.2 microdeletion in a maternal inv(4)(p15q31) fetus with increased nuchal translucency
patient: A 30-year-old woman was referred for genetic counseling and prenatal diagnosis at 19 weeks of gestation in the Center for Reproductive Medicine and Center for Prenatal Diagnosis of First Hospital of Jilin University. Nineteen weeks sonography findings indicated that increased nuchal translucency was detected in prenatal ultrasound. And the woman had a history of spontaneous abortion. There was no teratogenic exposure or infectious diseases during mother pregnancy. She and her husband claimed that they were nonconsanguineous and healthy, and no family histories of diabetes mellitus or congenital malformations were found. The study protocol was approved by the Ethics Committee of the First Hospital of Jilin University (No.2019–283), and the informed written consents were obtained from this couple for publication of this case report and accompanying images.
